events.title: Donald Trump's first trip to Moscow at Soviet invitation
events.description: Trump travels to Moscow and Leningrad with Ivana at the invitation of the Soviet government. The trip is arranged and hosted by Intourist (the Soviet state travel agency known to be a KGB front) to discuss building a luxury hotel near Red Square. Trump receives VIP treatment and tours potential hotel sites. According to former KGB operatives, Trump was likely surveilled during his stay and possibly fed talking points encouraging him to enter politics. Though no Moscow project materialized at the time, this trip marked Trump's first direct engagement with Soviet officials at the height of the Cold War.

moneyFlow.description: While the exact financial arrangements of Trump's Moscow trip are not publicly documented, the Soviet government through Intourist (a KGB front) covered the costs of Trump's VIP accommodations, transportation, and entertainment within the USSR. This form of hospitality, valued at approximately $50,000, represented an investment by the Soviet government in cultivating Trump as a business partner and potentially as a political asset. As standard Soviet practice for high-profile foreign visitors, this all-expenses-paid luxury treatment was designed to impress Trump and make him favorably disposed toward Soviet interests.

sources.description: The Hidden History of Trump's First Trip to Moscow - POLITICO Magazine
sources.citation: According to The Art of the Deal, Trump and Ivana 'flew to Moscow' in July 1987 to scout potential sites for a hotel. Trump wrote that he toured 'a half dozen potential sites for a hotel, including several near Red Square.'

events.title: Trump places full-page political ads in major newspapers
events.description: Shortly after returning from Moscow, Trump spends approximately $100,000 to place full-page advertisements in the New York Times, Washington Post, and Boston Globe. The ads contain an open letter titled "There's nothing wrong with America's Foreign Defense Policy that a little backbone can't cure," criticizing U.S. allies for not paying their fair share for defense. The content closely echoes Soviet propaganda themes of the time, leading some intelligence experts to suggest Trump may have been influenced by his Soviet hosts during his recent Moscow trip.

moneyFlow.description: Trump spent approximately $100,000 on full-page political advertisements in three major U.S. newspapers (New York Times, Washington Post, and Boston Globe) shortly after returning from his Moscow trip. This expenditure represented Trump's first significant investment in political messaging. The timing and content of these ads - criticizing U.S. defense policies in ways that echoed Soviet talking points - has led some intelligence experts to suggest a potential connection to his recent Soviet meetings, though Trump has maintained they represented his independent political views.

sources.description: The Hidden History of Trump's First Trip to Moscow - POLITICO Magazine
sources.citation: Trump's first trip to Soviet Moscow in 1987 looks, with hindsight, to be part of a pattern. The dossier by former British intelligence officer Christopher Steele is very specific about the timing of Trump's visits to Moscow.

sources.description: Trump Recruited as Moscow Asset Says Ex-KGB Spy Chief - Kyiv Post
sources.citation: After his Moscow trip, Trump took out full-page newspaper advertisements in the New York Times, Washington Post, and Boston Globe with the headline: "There's nothing wrong with America's Foreign Defense Policy that a little backbone can't cure."

events.title: Trump purchases the yacht Nabila from Adnan Khashoggi
events.description: Trump acquires the 282-foot megayacht Nabila for approximately $29 million from Saudi arms dealer Adnan Khashoggi (via the Sultan of Brunei as intermediary). The yacht, one of the world's largest, was previously owned by Khashoggi, who was facing financial troubles and was later indicted in the U.S. for fraud related to the Marcos regime. Trump renamed it the Trump Princess and used it as both a personal plaything and to entertain high-rollers for his casinos. This purchase linked Trump to Khashoggi's international network of arms dealing and clandestine finance.

moneyFlow.description: The $29 million acquisition of Adnan Khashoggi's yacht Nabila (renamed Trump Princess) represented a major luxury purchase for Trump, conducted through the Sultan of Brunei as an intermediary. Trump spent an additional $8.5 million refurbishing the vessel. This transaction connected Trump to Khashoggi, a controversial Saudi arms dealer with ties to global intelligence agencies and various financial scandals. The yacht served as both a personal luxury item and a business asset for entertaining high-rollers at Trump's casinos, but would later be sold during Trump's financial difficulties in the early 1990s.

sources.description: Kingdom 5KR - Wikipedia
sources.citation: After Khashoggi ran into financial problems, he sold the yacht to the Sultan of Brunei, who in turn sold it to Donald Trump for $29 million. After buying it, Trump spent $8.5 million on refurbishments.

His strategic flattery, described by his daughter as working 'like honey to a bee,' led to discussions about a potential Moscow hotel project and Trump's 1987 trip to the USSR.

entity-015.name: KGB (Committee for State Security)
entity-015.description: Soviet intelligence agency that took interest in Donald Trump's activities in the 1980s, shared intelligence with Czechoslovak StB.

entity-016.name: KGB
entity-016.description: Soviet foreign intelligence and domestic security service. Received information on Trump via the Czechoslovak StB, and later directly targeted Trump during his 1987 Moscow visit through Intourist (a KGB front). Internal directives in the mid-1980s specifically called for recruiting influential foreigners with traits like 'narcissism and corruption.'

entity-020.name: Soviet Government
entity-020.description: Government of the Soviet Union. Oversaw KGB operations and outreach to Western business figures during the final decades of the Cold War. Through Ambassador Dubinin and the state tourism agency Intourist, facilitated Trump's 1987 visit to Moscow to discuss a potential hotel project.
